prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: water 96 GHz SiO J2-1 for reference

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution, achieved in Baseband-3. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The SiO masers are observed at the highest available resolution to use all 3 lines as "supporting evidence" and possibly self-calibration. Since the main goal is not their detailed analysis ~0.5 km/s is adequate.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 80 mas will allow components >200 mJy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >80 mJy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 20 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~200 mJy (see below). About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~2 mJy star at SNR ~20.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 60 mas will allow components >160 mJy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration; time on target is ~5 min as shorter saves almost no time overall. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >80 mJy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 20 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~160 mJy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~3 mJy star at SNR ~30.

The spectral resolutions required are ~0.1km/s for water masers and 3 km/s for removing contaminating lines from continuum. This produces a data rate less than 2% above 12 MB/s, which we hope is acceptable.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 35 mas will allow components >95 mJy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration; time on target is ~5 min as shorter saves almost no time overall. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 20 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~95 mJy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~7 mJy star at SNR ~55, adequate for self-calibration if necessary.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinemations. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 45 mas will allow components >150 mJy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration; time on target is ~5 min as shorter saves almost no time overall. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >320 mJy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 25 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~150 mJy (see below). About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~11 mJy star at SNR ~55, adequate for self-calibration if necessary.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinemations. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 40 mas will allow components >150 mJy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration; time on target is ~5 min as shorter saves almost no time overall. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >320 mJy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Although the well-known 321-GHz line is likely to be at least 10 Jy, the 331-GHz line is weaker and also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 35 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~150 mJy (see below). About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~12 mJy star at SNR ~45, adequate for self-calibration if necessary.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinemations. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 40 mas will allow 325-GHz components >530 mJy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >320 mJy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. The well-known 325-GHz maser is likely to exceed 10 Jy but the 326 and 336 GHz lines will be fainter and, also, detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 100 mJy RMS this will be possible for 325-GHz maser components >~530 mJy (see below). Even for fainter masers, a 3-sigma detection will confirm whether they are insde or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. Better noise and accuracy will be achieved for the 326 and 336 GHz lines.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~12 mJy star at SNR ~80, adequate for self-calibration if necessary (NB the continuum baseband is around 336 GHz, providing better sensitivity than the line representative frequency of 325 GHz used for the estimate above of S/N 17).

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinemations. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~14 mJy star at SNR ~60, adequate for self-calibration if necessary.

The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

Time on target is ~5 min as shorter saves almost no time overall. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 50 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~470 mJy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~17 mJy star at SNR ~50, adequate for self-calibration if necessary.

Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 55 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~520 mJy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~17 mJy star at SNR ~40, adequate for self-calibration if necessary.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest available angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 70 mas will allow components >2 Jy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 200 mJy RMS at 439 GHz this will be possible for components >~2 Jy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. The sensitivity and accuracy will be better at 437 GHz. About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~19 mJy star at SNR ~20 (note that the actual placement of the continuum spw is in regions with better atmospheric transmission than the representative frequency in a line spw).

We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 110 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~880 mJy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~22 mJy star at SNR ~30, adequate for self-calibration if necessary (note that the actual placement of the continuum spw is in regions with better atmospheric transmission than the representative frequency in a line spw).

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 60 mas will allow components >2 Jy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. Even if the masers do not exceed 1 Jy, we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 250 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~2 Jy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, detecting the anticipated ~22 mJy star at SNR ~10.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 45 mas will allow components >1.5 Jy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 250 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~1.5 Jy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~32 mJy star at SNR ~15.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. The 658-GHz maser is very bright but detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting, especially since it has previously been observed in VY CMa to have a very surprisingly large extent. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 230 mJy RMS this will be possible for components >~1.4 Jy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~36 mJy star at SNR ~20.

The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 35 mas will allow components >2 Jy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 430 mJy RMS this will be possible if components are >~2 Jy (see below). Better sensitivity and accuracy will be achieved for the 793-GHz maser than for the representative frequency 788-GHz maser. Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~48 mJy star at SNR ~15. NB the spectral windows used for continuum are in a more sensitive part of the spectrum than the representative frequency.

The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 660 mJy RMS this will be possible if 832-GHz components are >~3.1 Jy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~48 mJy star at SNR ~18. NB the spectral windows used for continuum are in a more sensitive part of the spectrum than the representative frequency.

Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~52 mJy star at SNR ~13.

The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 250 mJy RMS this will be possible if components are >~1.2 Jy (see below). Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~52 mJy star at SNR ~20.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 30 mas will allow components >2. Jy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 500 mJy RMS this will be possible if components are >~2 Jy (see below). Better sensitivity and accuracy will be achieved for the 899 and 902 GHz masers than for the representative frequency 906-GHz maser. Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~57 mJy star at SNR ~10. NB the spectral windows used for continuum are in a more sensitive part of the spectrum than the representative frequency.

For water maser detection and characterisation, we want to cover more than the maximum likely spectral extent at ~0.1 km/s resolution. The high resolution is necessary to confirm maser action and to investigate the degree of line narrowing, a diagnostic of the saturation state. We expect to see multiple water maser clumps, each typically 3 km/s in spectral extent, spread over up to ~60 km/s, located in different parts of the maser shell. We have chosen to observe the 939 and 941 GHz lines in a smaller velocity span for efficiency, since their peaks are likely to fall within this range and, as lines from high energy levels, they are likely to fall within the inner CSE before maximum velocities are attained. The high spectral resolution will also help to avoid blending when accurately measuring the clump positions (see above) and deriving the 3D morphology and kinematics. Comparison with the positions of other transitions will then test the maser models.
The remaining basebands are used for continuum, but, because we expect some contaminating lines, we use ~3 km/s resolution to make removal easier. This will also increase the legacy value of the data.

We want the highest avaliable angular resolution in order to pinpoint the maser clumps; 30 mas will allow components >2 Jy to be fitted with the required 7.5 mas accuracy (see above), using (position error) ~ (beamsize)/(SNR) for narrow channels with relatively poor uv coverage. The largest angular scale is set by the water maser shell, unlikely to exceed 400 mas diameter.

We use the line in the less sensitive part of the spectrum as the representative frequency to ensure adequate bandpass calibration. We wish to image line emission in narrow enough channels to ensure water masing can be distinguished, i.e. ~0.1 km/s, used as the main sensitivity criterion. Any emission detected >2 Jy will have a brightness temperature >50000 K, also confirming maser action. Masers are commonly a few Jy or more but also detecting the line wings will allow more accurate spectral and spatial fitting. We want to be able to ascertain maser positions to 7.5 mas accuracy (average size of water maser clumps); for 500 mJy RMS this will be possible if components are >~2 Jy (see below). Better sensitivity and accuracy will be achieved for the higher frequency masers than for the representative frequency 923-GHz maser. Even for fainter 3-sigma components we will be able to see whether they are inside or outside the 50-mas radius dust formation zone.
About half the bandwidth will probably be useful for continuum, easily detecting the anticipated ~60 mJy star at SNR ~10. NB the spectral windows used for continuum are in a more sensitive part of the spectrum than the representative frequency.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water maser transitions never before imaged (many not even detected) can now be resolved by ALMA and used to test maser excitation models. 44 masing transitions are accessible, tracing a range of pumping mechanisms, temperatures (energy levels 200-thousands K), gas number densities, radiation and velocity fields. Prior to ALMA's expanded capabilities, 15-16 have detections and only 4 have been imaged. Red supergiant stars have some of the brightest known masers and of these, our target, VX Sgr, has the most symmetric (on most scales), easily-modelled wind. Only ALMA can distinguish maser species which are segregated or co-propagate, inside or outside the dust formation zone, on the 10-au wind clumping scale, and simultaneously locate the star. This will reveal not only the kinematics and morphology but also small-scale physical conditions in evolved-star winds, tackling issues such as the evolution of clumpiness. These observations will lead to well-constrained maser models and identify fiducial transitions as tools for studying warm molecular gas in star-forming regions or active galaxies as well as stellar winds.
